description: This game plays an awful lot like mid-90s classic Escape Velocity, which has another (and superior) open source successor in the form of Endless Sky. I'd recommend that over Naev since it is more fully-featured. Still, Naev has some interesting changes to the basic Escape Velocity formula, such as a more detailed simulation model. It's well worth your time but I'm afraid development is at a virtual standstill.
summary: An Escape Velocity-like with real promise

description: It was an interesting game to try. But it got boring in parts because there was little going on but moving between planets. Only after playing for 2 days - seemed like 2 years - did I get to interesting missions and then they were impossible to pass. Ships shooting from out of range of your weapons so you cant hit back. There was also a mission for an engine test, of course, the engine failed, but really! Did the whole game have to slow to a crawl, and have to fight literally 100's of enemies over a 2 hours space? That's not playability, that repetitive boring BS. If I could sue the authors for my time I would, don't waste yours playing this. Pick an alternative, any alternative. Go play with dolls, but not this.
summary: Similar to XBTF but without the graphics and playability

description: Yeah, technically Naev came first. But the two are VERY similar. If you like Escape Velocity and Endless Sky, you'll be right at home in Naev.
Naev isn't nearly as good as Endless Sky, but the backstory is really cool and the space graphics are stunning.
summary: Not as good as Endless Sky, but I liked it

description: I like this game, but there are a few issues. I can't even travel to some star systems at all, and it always results in a crash.
There is a more up to date version as a 64bit AppImage here https://github.com/naev/naev/releases/download/v0.8.2/naev-0.8.2-win64.exe
